thread.title: It's a wooden spoon for Ainsley Harriott as TV chef joins male exodus from Strictly
thread.title_full: It's a wooden spoon for Ainsley Harriott as TV chef joins male exodus from Strictly

title: It's a wooden spoon for Ainsley Harriott as TV chef joins male exodus from Strictly
text:
It's a wooden spoon for Ainsley Harriott as TV chef joins male exodus from Strictly It's a wooden spoon for Ainsley Harriott as TV chef joins male exodus from Strictly Share 
Ainsley Harriott has said he is “disappointed” to be the fourth celebrity to exit Strictly Come Dancing. 
“I gave it my best. I really did,” said the celebrity chef, who had been partnered with professional Natalie Lowe. 
“I hope it goes down that I entertained people and I showed that it’s such a lovely skill to acquire. I would have liked to have done a little bit more, especially for Natalie because she’s such a lovely person.” Ainsley Harriott and Natalie Lowe with Tess Daly (Guy Levy/BBC) 
The 58-year-old had no regrets. “I’m happy to have been part of it,” he said. “You get so engrossed in the whole competition, the people, the discipline and everything. 
“It was a happy experience. Of course I’m disappointed, I’d like to have gone on for a few more weeks at least, but that’s Strictly for you. You can never tell what’s going to happen and that’s what makes it the show it is.” 
Strictly has now lost its fourth male celebrity in a row as Ainsley follows Iwan Thomas, Anthony Ogogo and Daniel O’Donnell out of the competition. Ainsley said he has no regrets (Guy Levy/BBC) Promoted stories 
Asked to account for the gender quirk, the chef said: “Over the years, we have seen that the male dancers with women have come out on top, maybe because the men are the ones that lead. 
“Maybe that’s a slight sort of advantage instead of being an amateur like me and trying to lead a brilliant dancer like Natalie.” 
Genial Ainsley faced pop star Jamelia in the dreaded dance-off when the judges’ scores were combined with the results of the viewers’ votes. Ainsley faced Jamelia in the final dance-off (Guy Levy/BBC) 
Ainsley and his professional partner Lowe reprised their jive to Shake, Rattle and Roll, while Jamelia and Tristan MacManus performed their foxtrot to Celine Dion’s Because You Loved Me. 
After both couples had danced again, judges Craig Revel Horwood, Bruno Tonioli and Darcey Bussell all chose to save Jamelia. 
Head judge Len Goodman’s vote was academic, but he agreed with his fellow panellists. Judges Craig Revel Horwood, Darcey Bussell, Len Goodman and Bruno Tonioli (Guy Levy/BBC) 
When asked by co-presenter Tess Daly if he had enjoyed his time on the show, Ainsley said: “It’s been absolutely amazing.” 
The London-born chef was philosophical about his departure, despite scoring more than bottom-placed broadcaster Jeremy Vine. 
“There’s been occasions where people have been top of the leaderboard, or near enough top of the leaderboard, and been in the dance off,” he said during his exit interview. The TC chef said he did his best (Guy Levy/BBC) 
“This happened to me on a couple of occasions, once I was able to rectify it, last night it didn’t quite go according to plan.” 
Ainsley praised his fellow celebrity contestants, but struggled to choose a winner from pop star Jay McGuiness, actresses Helen George and Kellie Bright and broadcaster Anita Rani. 
“Jeremy Vine was saying: ‘Jay. He’s so fantastic, we would be his father!’ I thought: ‘I don’t know about that, Jeremy. Maybe you could be, I couldn’t be!’ Jeremy Vine and Karen Clifton (Guy Levy/BBC) 
“He’s looking strong, he’s coming out with some fantastic dances. Helen, Anita, even Kellie – just looking great. It’s one of those four, personally. I think they just produce fabulous dances week after week after week.” 
After rubbing shoulders with an EastEnders star, Ainsley was asked if he would like a spot in the BBC One soap. 
“They’re all professional actors, I’m a chef,” he chuckled. “Maybe I could in there and fry a few eggs. ‘Bacon butty. Number three! Who’s having the cous cous?’ They’d probably go, ‘what’s this coo coo stuff?’” Ainsley had good things to say about Jay McGuiness (Guy Levy/BBC) 
Sunday’s results show also featured a performance from rock legend Bryan Adams. 
The remaining 11 couples will return to the dance floor next weekend for Strictly’s Halloween special. Share article 
Strictly Come Dancing is broadcast on Saturday October 31 at 6.35pm. Promoted Stories
